In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,080,000 VND to buy canned food, rice, beer and soft drinks for her grocery store. She wants to use the profit to raise her children well.

loans.use: to buy canned food, rice, beer and soft drinks for her grocery store.

loans.name: Mario Isabel

texts.es:
El señor Mario Isabel  tiene 44 años de edad. Vive en el municipio Chichigalpa, cerca de compañía licorera,  conocido por su producción de caña de azúcar y licorera. Es uno de los lugares más caliente de Nicaragua.

Desde hace 3 años le fue diagnosticado con infección renal crónica, conocida comúnmente como “creatinina” el trabajo desde  su niñez en corte de caña de azúcar, riego y labores de campo. Por padecer de esta terrible enfermedad, ninguna empresa está dispuesta a darle empleo formal  a pesar de ser aun joven.

Al ser diagnosticado con esta, enfermedad a pesar de ser un hombre aun fuerte  no lo contratan para evitar gastos médicos.
 
Actualmente vive de una pensión reducida  con la cual asume gastos familiares, cuenta con un pequeño negocio de subsistencia  que consiste en venta de dulces artesanales, los cuales con gran dificultada los lleva a vender con su esposa al campo donde los cortadores de caña de azúcar; tiene 2 hijos que aun se encuentran cursando la primaria y ellos también participan en la venta de los dulces para apoyar el sostenimiento de la familia además que de este negocio  se apoya para cubrir gran parte de sus gastos médicos.

El se levanta a las 4 de la mañana todos los días a realizar sus labores cotidianas y posteriormente se dedica a la elaboración de los dulces y consecutivamente a la venta de los mismos,  y cuando puede salir, ayuda e a su esposa a cobrar los pagos pendientes.

El destino del crédito es para cubrir gastos familiares e invertir en el negocio; Venta de dulces artesanales, bollitos de coco, zapoyol,

El señor Mario Isabel agradeciendo a CEPRODEL y Kiva ya de esta manera está mejorando su calidad de vida y la de su familia y pide que se les siga apoyando para que todas las personas que sufren de esta enfermedad sean apoyados  así como lo estamos haciendo con el…
texts.en:
Mario Isabel is 44-years-old. He lives in the municipality Chichgalpa, near a distilling company, known for the production of sugar cane and distillation. This is one of the hottest locations in Nicaragua. 

For the last 3 years of he was diagnosed by renal chronic infection, known commonly like "creatinina.” His work since childhood has been to cut sugar cane and irrigation of the fields. Due to his suffering from the terrible disease, no company is ready to formally employ him despite the fact that he is young person. 

Since he was diagnosed with this disease, despite being a strong man, no one will hire him to avoid medical costs. Nowadays he lives on a reduced pension with which he pays his family costs. He counts on a small business that consists of sale of artisanal candy. Which with great difficulty he sells them with his wife to the field where the cutters of sugar cane are; He has two children that are in elementary school and they participate in the sale of candy to supplement the family income. This business covers the majority of his medical expenses.  

He wakes up at 4am every day to complete his daily labors and after he devotes himself to the production of sweets and consecutively to the sale of the sweets. When he can leave he helps his wife to charge the pending payments. The loan will be used to cover family expenses and invest in the business: sale of artisanal candies, coconut balls, and Zapoyol. 

Mario Isabel is grateful to Kiva for improving the quality of his life and that of his family.  He asks that all the persons who suffer from this disease are supported in the same way that he is supported.

loans.use: to sell artisanal candy, coconut balls, and zapoyol.

loans.name: Than

texts.en:
Than was born in 1968. She has a son who is a carpenter. Her husband is a carpenter, too. His income is about 3,500,000 dong (VND). Than raises chickens and pigs, and grows rice, to earn a living. She has done this work for 10 years. Her income is about 3,500,000 dong (VND). Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 dong (VND) per month. 

Than has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2008. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,392,000 dong (VND), and she repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,736,000 dong (VND) to buy food for pigs and chickens in her farm. She wants to use her profit to invest in her husband's carpentry workshop.

loans.use: to buy food for pigs and chickens in her farm.

loans.name: Nhi

texts.en:
Nhi was born in 1967. She has two children who are carpenters. Her husband and she are carpenters, too. Her salary is about 5,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). Her family’s total earnings are about 20,000,000 VND per month. 

Nhi has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2008. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,392,000 VND, and she repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,736,000 VND to buy carpentry tools (a wood planer machine and a wood sawing machine) to do carpentry more productively.

loans.use: to buy carpentry tools (a wood planer machine and a wood sawing machine) to do carpentry more productively.

loans.name: Orzigul

texts.en:
Orzigul is married and has one adult child. Her husband is a worker and his income is small. She tries to do all the best for her child. She sews wonderful womens' dresses which can’t be sewn by just any seamstress. 

Orzigul decided to start her own business and to do this she studied a course called " To Get Ahead" at a women's organization. From this course, she got enough skills about business, but her sewing machine is an old design. She is asking for a loan of 1,000 Tajikistan Somonis (TJS) to buy a new sewing machine for starting her new business. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine for starting her new business.

loans.name: Reginaldo

texts.es:
Reginaldo, solicita su crédito para surtir la tienda, comprando más productos para la temporada que se acerca, comprara golosinas, jugos, sodas, flores, lociones, azúcar, entre otros productos que le permitan satisfacer las demandas de los clientes.
Su efecto con el préstamo anterior, mejoro su inventario, durante este periodo presencio la muerte del padre de su esposa, por lo demás su familia se mantiene, los ingresos y el deseo de mejorar cada día y mas por la temporada que se acerca.
texts.en:
Reginaldo is requesting a loan to stock his store with more products for the approaching season. He will buy candy, juice, soft drinks, flowers, lotions, and sugar, as well as other products to satisfy the demands of his customers. 

The previous loan improved his inventory. During this period the father of his wife passed away. Apart from that, his family is doing well because of the income from the business, the desire to get better each day, and the approaching season.

loans.use: to buy candy, juice, soft drinks, flowers, lotions, and sugar.

loans.name: Eliodoro

texts.es:
El señor Eliodoro  tiene 40 años de edad. Vive en el municipio Chichigalpa, un lugar en el oeste de Nicaragua, conocido por su producción de caña de azúcar y licorera. Es uno de los lugares más caliente de Nicaragua.

Desde hace tres  años le fue diagnosticado con infección renal crónica, conocida comúnmente como “creatinina” el trabajo desde  su niñez en corte de caña de azúcar.

 El mantiene 4 hijos que aun estudian la primaria y su esposa quien la apoya en su pequeño negocio de subsistencia; Ya que al ser diagnosticado con esta enfermedad, a pesar de ser un hombre joven no lo contratan para evitar gastos médicos.

El se levanta a las 5 de la mañana todos los días a realizar sus labores cotidianas y posteriormente se dedica a la venta, además el mata cerdos una vez por semana para obtener ingresos en la comercialización de la carne, piel y su derivados de los cerdos.

El destino del crédito es para cubrir gastos familiares e invertir en el negocio.

El señor Eliodoro agradeciendo a CEPRODEL y Kiva ya de esta manera está mejorando su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Eliodoro, 40, lives in the town of Chichigalpa in the western part of Nicaragua, known for sugar cane and distillery. It is one of the hottest places in Nicaragua.

Three years ago he was diagnosed with chronic kidney infections, known commonly as "creatinina". He has worked since childhood cutting sugar cane. He has 4 children in primary school and his wife helps him with a small business that they subsist on, because after being diagnosed with this illness, in spite of being a young man, he doesn't get hired so that owners can avoid his medical costs.

He gets up at 5am every day to do his daily chores and then begins his sales. He also kills pigs once a week to get money from selling their meet, skin and other derivatives.

The loan will be used to cover familial costs and invest in the business. Eliodoro thanks CEPRODEL and Kiva because through these loans he is improving his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to sell ropes, cords and plastics.

loans.name: Ana Betty

texts.es:
Ana, solicita su crédito para la compra de mercadería para la tienda, comprando gaseosas, leña, maíz, golosinas, bolsas, entre otros productos que son los necesarios para que su negocio pueda atender la demanda de  los clientes.
Con el préstamo anterior tuvo un efecto positivo, ya que durante este tiempo instalo la energía eléctrica en el hogar, mejoro la mercadería en la tienda, en su hogar todos se encuentran bien, manteniendo su número de miembros, sus hijos se encuentran estudiando.
texts.en:
Ana asks for a loan to buy merchandise for her store including sodas, firewood, corn, snacks, bags and other products that she needs to meet her customers' demands. 

The previous loan had a positive impact, since during that time she installed electricity in her home and improved the merchandise in her store. Everyone in her household is well - the same number of family members - and her children are in school.

loans.use: to buy sodas, firewood, corn, snacks and bags.

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en:
Katerina is 66 years old and married, with seven children. She makes and sells kava bowls, woven mats, hats, and other traditional crafts to earn a living.  She has been doing this for two years. Katerina has requested a loan to buy tools, pandanus, and woods for carving. (Pandanus is a genus of shrubs and trees prevalent on South Pacific islands, the leaves of which are used in traditional crafts, especially for weaving into mats.)

Katerina plans to use her profits to improve her business. She joined SPBD in 2010 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy pandanus, woods for carving, and carving knives.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María de 53 años, convive con Luis, con quien tiene un hijo de 19 años. Ellos viven en una casa propia ubicada en un distrito rural. María es una madre dulce y una mujer empeñosa. Su principal actividad es el negocio. Gracias a la ubicación de su hogar (al lado de la carretera central), logró abrir un establecimiento donde expende productos comestibles como: refrescos, panes, sándwich, pasteles, queques, miel, queso, y otros. En esta actividad lleva como 7 años, y comenta que le va muy bien, especialmente los días sábados y domingos, por la mayor cantidad de visitantes. 
“Cada quince días realizó las compras para mi local, porque algunos productos son perecibles, pero al mes compró los otros productos como bebidas gaseosas”, comenta.
Mientras tanto su esposo se hace cargo de las parcelas de terrenos sembrando papas y arvejas. María también apoya en estas actividades. Ahora tendrá que realizar más compras para su negocio, por lo que requiere de su apoyo. Éste es su préstamo número 4 con MFP. Como en anteriores créditos, dice que será puntual en el pago de las cuotas. Pertenece al banco comunal “Progreso Huayounioc”, donde es la presidenta y socia muy participativa.
Con el dinero podrá adquirir la mercadería necesaria para abastecer su puesto de ventas (Panes, quesos, queques, biscochuelos, miel, manjar blanco, etc.
texts.en:
Maria, 53, lives with Luis, with whom she has a 19 year old son. They own their home in a rural district. Maria is a sweet mother and a dedicated woman.. She runs a business. Thanks to the location of her home (next to the main highway) she was able to open a shop where she sells food like sodas, breads, sandwiches, cakes, honey, cheese and other things. She has been doing this for 7 years and says it's going very well, especially on Saturdays and Sundays when she gets most of her visitors.

"Every 15 days I make purchases for my store, because some items are perishable. Once a month I buy other products like sodas," she says. 

Meanwhile, her husband works on their land planting potatoes and peas. Maria also helps him with this. 

Now they will have to make more purchases for the store, which is why she needs your help. This will be her fourth loan with MFP. As with the previous loans, she says that they sill be punctual in making her payments. She belongs to the village bank "Progreso Huayounioc", where she is the president and a very active member. 

With the money from the loan she will be able to buy the merchandise she needs to stock her shop (bread, cheese, cakes, sponge cake, honey, blancmange, etc).

loans.use: to buy bread, cheese, cakes, sponge cake, honey, blancmange.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es: La Sra. Guillermina tiene 46 años y es casada con 3 hijos que tienen 21, 17 y  12 años,  ella se dedica a la venta de carne menudencias de res, tiene su puesto de venta en una zona muy concurrida de la zona central de ciudad de La Paz, está en decima secuencia de su  préstamo con muestras institución es cliente antigua, la Sra. Guillermina  va a usar este préstamo para la compra de  carne y un heladera ya que le hace falta para conservar su carne fresca, la Sra. Guillermina es una persona muy emprendedora y trabajadora, se siente feliz y agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado, ya que con el anterior crédito le fue muy bien creció en su actividad y mejoro sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Guillermina is 46-years-old and is married with 3 children that are 21, 17, and 12 years old. She works in the sale of cut beef. She has a stand in the zone near the central zone of the city of La Paz. 

Guillermina is in the tenth sequence of her loan with an institution as a long-term client. Guillermina will use this loan to purchase meat and a cooler that she is missing to conserve the fresh meat. 

Guillermina is a hard working person and she is happy and grateful for the institution for the help provided. With the last loan she was able to grow her business and improve her income.

loans.use: to purchase a cooler and odds and ends for her business

loans.name: Nuri 4 Group

texts.en:
Tjasiah, a 47-year-old, started her own business in 1984. She has a business making and selling “Nasi Uduk”. Nasi uduk is a dish made of rice, cooked with coconut milk, mixed with chicken or egg, noodles and fermented soy.  It is usually eaten after prayer in the morning as their breakfast or before they start their day. 
From her business, she was able to pay school fees and send her child to receive a bachelor's degree. Now, Tjasiah has 2 children that still go to school. With this loan, she wants to expand her business and open a grocery store. She faces many competitors daily and routinely wakes up early in the morning but she enjoys it because she already has loyal customers and quiet a decent income from this business.

loans.use: to add capital to open a grocery store

loans.name: Tenisi

texts.en: Tenisi is 49 years old and married with 4 children. She wants to start a small business making and selling BBQ in her community. To do this, she needs a loan to purchase a box of chicken legs, sausages, lamb flaps etc to start her new business. In the future, Tenisi hopes to continue her business to satisfy the family needs. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a box of chicken legs, sausages, lamb flaps, oil

loans.name: Ayurzana

texts.en:
Ayurzana is a 62-year-old woman who lives with her husband, daughter and niece in a small house in Sukhbaatar district, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband works at City Power Plant as an electrical engineer. Her daughter stays home taking care of her daughter and her parents. 

Ayurzana has been operating various types of businesses since 2001. She has been selling clothes and shoes for a long time and has built strong relationships with her customers at the local market. She said, "There is lot of competition within the clothes retail sector, and I want to start a cosmetics sales business at the counter I rent at the market." Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 600000 MNT to purchase cosmetic goods to sell. She is a welcoming, responsible and neat woman.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic goods to sell.

loans.name: Amarjargal

texts.en: Mr. Amarjargal is 24 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a Ger in Sainshand soum, in the Dornogobi Province of Mongolia. His wife Dashmaa works at a local shopping center as a saleswoman. Their one year old daughter Margad-Erdene stays home with the parents-in-law during the day. For years before starting his own business, he worked at a DVD and CD rental and sales counter and gained experience in this business. He started his own DVD and CD shop in September 2011. He imports DVDs and CDs from Erlian, China once a month with a budget of 700'000 MNT. He is planning to expand his business to improve his family's living conditions and is requesting a loan of 2'000'000 MNT to import DVDs and CDs to sell at his rental counter to customers at the local market. He is hardworking, welcoming and friendly.

loans.use: to import DVDs and CDs to sell at his rental counter to customers at the local market

loans.name: Gulnaz's Group

texts.en:
Gulnaz is a 48-year-old widow with 2 sons and 3 daughters. Her husband died of diabetes when her children were at an early age. Since then, she has been looking after her children and paying all household expenses alone by providing tailoring services in her community. She faced a very difficult time after the death of her husband. She recently had a uterus operation but she is still working with full delegation to provide for the family needs. She works 8 hours a day. 
In spite of working full time, she takes care of all the housework and makes sure that she can fulfill all of her children's needs.  

All of the income which comes from her tailoring business goes to the household expenses due to which she is unable to save any amount for her children’s future but she is very much thankful to Allah Almighty that she is having her own house to live in. 

Her older son owns a small shop selling fried chicken at the corner of the street but his income is insufficient and the other one did matriculation*** and took some computer courses as well but he is jobless. Her one daughter did matriculation and got married and now has 2 sons, while the youngest one has recently completed B.com (Bachelor of Commerce)

Gulnaz, as a member of this 6-person lending group, has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase fabric and a separate sewing machine for her tailoring business since she currently has only one sewing machine which she uses for her tailoring business as well as for personal use. 

Gulnaz hopes that the loan will be beneficial to them. 

Note: In the picture Gulnaz holds a passbook in her hand.

***See this Wikipedia entry for a detailed explanation http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matriculation#Pakistan

loans.use: To purchase a new machine for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Salote

texts.en: Salote is a 38 year old married woman with five children. She catches and sells fresh fish in her community to earn a living. She has many years of experience with this business. Salote needs a loan to buy a fishing net to replace her old one. She plans to use her profits to help with the daily needs of her family. Salote has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net, canoe, and spear

loans.name: Ovilla

texts.en:
This is Ovilla, 37, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Isagani, a driver, and is a mother to their children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Ovilla operates a food stall. She sells street foods like chicken intestine, other chicken parts and barbecue that she sells in their community. She also has a variety store and vegetable vending business for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php13,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more raw products and supplies she uses in her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Ovilla dreams to be able to give her children a high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw products and supplies that she needs in her business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
This is Rebecca, 42, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Benigno, a driver and is the mother to their children. She together with her husband manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rebecca operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Rebecca hopes to give her children a high quality education and dreams to have a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Faaosofia

texts.en: Faaosofia is a 35 year old married woman with four children. She would like to start growing bananas and taro to earn a living. Faaosofia has requested a loan to buy a plant sprayer, chemicals, and bush knives. She has been a member of SPBD for one year. Faaosofia will use her profits to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, chemicals, bush knives, and a plant sprayer

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Sina is 34 years old and married with 6 children. She wants to start a small business making and selling rice and curry in her community. To do this, she needs a loan to purchase chicken quarters, rice, curry, oil, onion, salt, and flour. 

In the future, Sina hopes to continue her canteen and survive the future. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to purchase chicken quarters, rice, curry, oil, onion, salt, and flour.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is 34 years old and married with 4 children. She wants to start a small business making and selling pork buns in her community. To do this, she needs a loan to purchase pork, flour, oil, salt, onions, and soy sauce - all the things needed for her business. 

In the future, Lina hopes to expand her business. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to purchase pork, flour, oil, salt, onions, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Alaviga

texts.en: Alaviga is 37 years old and married with two children. She has a small garden where she grows cocoa that she sells in her community and at the market. She has been doing this for many years. Alaviga needs a loan to buy a plant sprayer, chemicals, fertilizer and bush knives. She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. Alaviga will use the profits from her sales to support her family.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, shovels, bush knives, and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Nuri 6 Group

texts.en:
Winarsih, 54 years old, started her own business in 2010. Her business is selling second-hand clothes. Over the last few weeks her income was reduced so she decided to start a  a new business. 

Her loan of 2,000,000 IDR will be used to sell fried macaroni mix with chili sauce. She will entrust the macaroni in some kiosks in her neighborhood. Many competitors and difficulty getting the goods are her obstacles to running this business, but she said  “I can learn many thing from the experience and find the best business for me”.

loans.use: add capital to start a new business.

loans.name: Moliai

texts.en:
Moliai is a 35-year-old married woman with 4 children. She would like to start growing bananas and taro to earn a living. 

Moliai has requested a loan to buy bush knives, chemicals, fertilizer, and a plant sprayer. She has been a member of SPBD for 1 year. Moliai will use her profits to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bush knives, chemicals, fertilizer, and a plant sprayer.

loans.name: Lupe

texts.en: Lupe is a 62-year-old married woman with nine children. She would like to start growing vegetables to earn a living. Lupe has requested a loan to buy a plant sprayer, chemicals, bush knives, and vegetable seeds. She has been a member of SPBD for two years. Lupe will spend her profits to improve her business.

loans.use: chemicals, fertilizer, veggie seeds, and gloves.

loans.name: Seine

texts.en:
Seine is 29 years old and married with 2 children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 3 years. 

Seine needs a loan to purchase fertilizers, a wheel barrow, shovels, and gloves to extend her business. She has been a member of SBPD since 2010. Seine will save the profits from her sales for her family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, a wheel barrow, shovels, and gloves.

loans.name: Enhnaran

texts.en:
Mrs. Enhnaran is 44 years old and lives with her husband, six children, and her niece in the Sukhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband, Bathuyag, is 45 and works at home producing hand made wooden tools and other equipment by order. Her children, Sod-Erdene, 23, and Bolortuya, 21, work at a private company; Mongonshagai, 18, and Anhiluuntsetseg, 17, are university students; Batnaran, 14, is in secondary school; and her youngest son, Chinbat, 4, goes to kindergarten. 

Mrs. Enhnaran and her husband work hard to educate their children and to live independently. She has been working as a salesperson at the local market for years, and now she is planning to open her own stationary and clothing business there. She is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to purchase inventory for her new business. She is a hardworking, honest, and friendly woman.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for her new stationary and clothing business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay school fees, add capital to her business, and buy a blender.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is a 42-year-old married woman and a mother of six children from Panglao, Bohol. She has been engaged in a fish-vending business for more than five years now. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Rosalie is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets and lead weights, buckets and fuel for the boat. Through this, her husband will be able to enhance his daily catch, thus giving them more fish to sell in the market. In the future, Rosalie aims to expand their business and save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and lead weights, buckets and fuel for the boat.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria, 46, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Ramon, a laborer and a mother to her children. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Gloria maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Gloria hopes to give her family a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Faau

texts.en:
Faau is a 60-year-old married woman with seven children. She makes and sells ice cakes in her community to earn a living. She has four years of experience.

Faau needs a loan to buy supplies like a sack of sugar, cordials, and foam cups. She plans to use her profits to support her family. Faau has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy supplies like sugar, cordials, and foam cups.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase beads and cloth for embroidery work.

loans.name: Dolester

texts.en:
Dolester is 51 years old and married with nine children.

Dolester works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 14,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

Dolester has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from food vending.

Dolester aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
Gulbahor is 50 years old. She is a hard-working woman, and her partner is a businessman. They have two children they love very much, and they live together in a  house.

For 17 years, Gulbahor has been selling a variety of fruits and vegetables, and she stores her merchandise in a local market. She makes periodic trips to accomplish her goal, and her partner currently helps her to purchase her merchandise.  As a result of the good results she is having, she wishes to increase her business by selling more fruits and vegetables.

She is asking for a loan of 3,000 TJS to buy fruits and vegetables for widening the assortment of her goods. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa is 53 years old and married with nine children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

For eight years, Felisa has been selling fish in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell. In the future, Felisa would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith works hard to support three children. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Judith requested a PHP 1,400 (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove.

She is getting the Envirofit cookstove because she wants to lessen the amount of firewood that she uses when cooking food for her family.

Judith is aware that by using the Envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase an Envirofit cookstove to lessen the amount of firewood that she uses when cooking food for her family.

loans.name: Zebiniso

texts.en:
Zebiniso is 41 years old, married and has eight children. Her husband is a pensioner. She owns a store, which is based in the local market. Here she offers all industrious goods and food items. She is one of the successful businesswomen in the local market and has many customers. 

To improve business, she is borrowing from the Imon International organization to buy food items for widening the assortment of her goods. She’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding her business before long.

loans.use: To buy food items for widening the assortment of her goods.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila is 70 years old and has three children. 

Mila is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Mila requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Mila has been raising pigs for eight years now, and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mila would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Abas produces kenkey (fermented corn dough) for sale. In the photo, Aba is covering the corn dough with banana leaves as a form of packaging. 

She is married to a farmer and has four dependents. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of the family.  

Aba needs this loan to purchase bags of maize for her kenkey production. With the new profit, Aba will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize for her kenkey (fermented corn dough) production.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a merchant from Loon, Bohol. She has been running a sari-sari store, or a variety store business, for several years now. She sells various goods to the people in the community. 

Elizabeth is asking for a loan to buy items to sell, such as canned goods, dry goods, snack foods, and toiletries. This will help her to attract more customers. Elizabeth dreams of making her business a success and saving money for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy more canned goods, dry goods, snack foods, and toiletries.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase stock of shopping bags

loans.name: Oysara

texts.en:
Oysara is 37 years old and lives with her child in the town where she has a food vending business. She sells a variety of foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and salads. With her profits, she pays for her child's schooling. She is an intelligent woman who says, "I will do all the best for my family."

Oysara is requesting a loan to purchase fruits and vegetables. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is a fish monger; she buys fresh fish from the market and fries them for sale. Ama has been selling fried fish for eight years now, and she is married with six  dependents.  

Ama uses her income to support her husband and to feed and clothe their children. Ama will use her loan to purchase fresh fish to fry for sale. She will expand her business with the new profit.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fish to fry for sale.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion works hard to support her family. She is single and has a general store business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 20 years.

Salvacion requested a 17,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell.

In the future, Salvacion would like to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
This is Linda, 54, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is a mother to her child. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Linda maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 24,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Linda hopes to live happily with her child and dreams of expanding her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise for her customers

loans.name: Adwowa

texts.en: Adwowa sells maize and groundnuts cooked together at Egyirfa near Cape Coast.  In the picture above, she is wrapping the maize and groundnuts with cone leaves as a form of packaging. Adowa has been in this business for 10 years. She uses her income for the general upkeep of her home. Adwowa will use her loan to purchase bags of maize and groundnuts for her business. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize and groundnuts

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 29 years old, married and supports a family of six. She runs a small-scale farming business on her farm nearby and this has been her income-generating business for the last 10 years. She gets an average monthly income of KES 43,000. 

She has borrowed a second loan of KES 40,000 after successfully repaying her previous loan. With this loan, she intends to purchase farm inputs for her business. She anticipates getting profits that she will use to expand her business by increasing her crops to meet her clients' demand. She also intends to save some money for her children's school fees.

Gladys hopes to improve her living standards and be financially stable. She also hopes to save money to enable her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua lives with her husband, who is a farmer, and her two children at Egyrafa near Cape Coast. For three years, Efua has sold raw rice and canned tomatoes. She uses her income to support her husband in paying their children’s school fees. Efua will use her loan to purchase bags of rice and boxes of canned tomatoes for sale. With the profits she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: purchase bags of rice and boxes of canned tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: For four years, Comfort has produced charcoal for sale at Egyirfa near Cape Coast. Comfort is married with three children. She uses her income to support her husband and to feed her children and pay their school fees. Comfort will use her loan to purchase fire wood to make charcoal to sell. With the profits from her expanded business Comfort will produce larger quantities of charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase fire wood to produce charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi cooks banku and serves it with okra soup and fish at Nygirfa near Cape Coast. She is married and has five children; her husband is a driver. She and her partner work to educate, feed, and clothe their children. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize, vegetables, fish, and other ingredients to cook her banku for sale. She hopes to use the profits from her business to open a food vending stall.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to make banku for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a small scale trader. For the past two years, she has sold ladies' underwear and children's dresses and underwear at Egyrifa near Cape Coast.

Mary is married, and she uses her income to help her husband pay utility bills and rent.  She needs this loan to enable her to purchase more underwear and ladies' and children's dresses to sell. With the profits, she plans to acquire a shop for the sale of her dresses.

loans.use: to purchase underwear and ladies' and children's dresses to sell.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 45 years old and married with four children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

For five years, Gina has operated a fishing business in the Philippines. She requested a 22,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy raw materials to repair her fishing boat.

In the future, Gina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to repair her fishing boat.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac lives together with his wife at Egyirfa near Cape Coast. Isaac produces charcoal for sale, which he has done for 20 years now. Isaac uses his  income to provide food and shelter for his family.  

Isaac will use his loan to purchase firewood in order to produce charcoal to sell. With the new profit from his expanded business, Isaac will produce the charcoal in a larger quantity.

loans.use: to purchase firewood to produce charcoal to sell

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
This is Thelma, 45, a resident of Taguig, Philippines. She is married to Hussain, a taxi driver, and she is a mother to her children. Together with her husband she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Thelma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 13,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Thelma hopes to give her children a good quality education and dreams of having a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. There she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God as she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Godelio

texts.en: Godelio is a 41-year-old married man and a father of four young children from Talibon, Bohol. He is engaged in the buying and selling of fish and other sea products. Godelio has been a member of CEVI for several years now. He joined CEVI because he wanted to avail himself of the financial services offered by the organization to the micro entrepreneurs like himself. He is asking for a new loan to buy more fish and other sea products to sell in the market. With this, he will be able to augment his sales and profit. Godelio hopes of making his business in the future. Moreover, he wants to save money for the schooling of his children.

loans.use: to buy more fish and other seafood to sell in the market.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy an autorickshaw for rickshaw transport business

loans.name: Geogina

texts.en: Geogina has been selling charcoal at Egyrifo near Cape Coast for the past two years. She is married to a carpenter and they have two children  She uses her income to feed her family and pay her children’s school fees. Geogina will use her loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Geogina wants to produce her own charcoal to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
This is Myrna, 42, a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Renilo, a community servant and a father to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their daily expenses.

Myrna operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a food stall where she sells burgers and french fries.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Myrna dreams of having a good life and hopes her grandchildren will have a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Batool's Group

texts.en:
Ms. Batool is an active and responsible mother of three children, two sons and a daughter. She is 39 years old and living in the city of Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband is an energetic mason. Within the meager salary of his income, Batool found it difficult to run the household and to fulfill the needs of her children. It compelled her to initiate a small business of hand-embroidery at home. 

Batool has an excellent hand-embroidery skills and has been running this business very successfully since 2006. She sells her beautifully hand-stitched and embroidery products in the market. She is running this business to contribute some amount to the family income and to keep herself busy as she does not like to waste her skills and precious time by sitting idle at home. Her business is successful and the demand for her embroidery products is increasing day by day. 

Currently her embroidery stock is almost finished so she wants to purchase some embroidery products to continue her business as her income plays a vital role in fulfilling the needs of the family members. 

For that reason, Batool, as a member of 7- person lending group has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase fabric and packs of threads of various colors. With the help of the loan amount, she will be able to purchase stock and sustain her embroidery business. She desires to expand her business in the future and to provide higher education for her children. 

Note: In the picture, Batool holding a pink passbook in her hand.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery supplies for her small hand-embroidery business.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa would like to take a further loan to buy new toys and care products for her childcare business. Her previous loan enabled her to provide better services for her kids. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business and her income, and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy toys and care products for her childcare business.

loans.name: Jesibel

texts.en:
This is Jesibel, She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan, which she used to purchase additional sacks of rice and more cell phone credits for retailing. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and for the family's household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a new loan, of 25,000 PHP, for her to buy additional sacks of rice and more cell phone credits to resell. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jesibel desires a successful business, a healthy body, and a peaceful and happy life. She also prays that she will be able to send all her children all the way through college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting, where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional sacks of rice, and more cell phone minutes, to resell.

loans.name: Jenalyn

texts.en: Jenalyn is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her store. NWTF is relisting Jenalyn's business profile in support of her efforts to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
This is Sharon, 49, a resident of Taguig, Philippines. Single, she manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Sharon operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands.

Sharon hopes to expand her business and dreams of having a good life by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
This is Mary, 60, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Vicente, a driver, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Mary oversees operations of their jeepney transportation business. 

Jeepneys were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for everyday travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines. 

Mary has one jeepney (14-16 person capacity). Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of her jeepney unit.

Mary dreams to have a good life with her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their jeepney unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for more equipment and beauty products needed in her business.

loans.name: Ma. Jeanita

texts.en:
This is Ma. Jeanita, 40, a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Sanny, a driver, and mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma. Jeanita operates a peanut butter-making business. What she basically does is buy raw peanuts and other ingredients needed in making her product from the market, process them then repack them and sell them per piece to individuals, general store owners and the local community. Peanut butter is repacked in 250 and 500 gram plastic bottles. She also sell accessories for additional income. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional stocks of raw ingredients used in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ma. Jeanita dreams of being able to give her all her children a good future and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have a growing network of customers. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ingredients and materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Umeri

texts.en:
Umeri is a 44-year-old married woman who has run a small general store in her community for many years. She sells various daily-use items at reasonable prices. Umeri has good communication skills and continues to retain many regular customers. Her husband is employed in a small factory and earns insufficient income to support his family on his own. This has motivated Umeri to help provide for her family by contributing to the family's income. 

Umeri wants to grow her business so she has requested a loan of 30,000 PKR to buy stocks of rice and flour from the market at lower rates. She then would be able to consistently meet the increasing demand. Umeri wishes to utilize part of the revenue for personal expenses and to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To buy stocks of rice and flour from the market at lower rates.

loans.name: Mahmadsafar

texts.en:
Mahmadsafar is 60 years old and is married with three children. Being a responsible father, he works hard every day to generate income so that he can cover his daily costs. Mahmadsafar is dedicated to his farming business, growing corn on his own land. In order to contribute to improving his family's living standards, he has worked hard from early morning till late evening for five years.

Mahmadsafar would like to develop his business so he is asking for a loan of 650 USD to purchase mineral fertilizers and seeds for the new planting season. He hopes that Kiva lenders won’t reject his loan and he thanks lenders in advance for their generosity.

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizers for the new planting season

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 42 years old and is married with one child. She works hard to provide for her family. Jocelyn runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 35,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

Jocelyn has been in this business for seven years and has previously received funds through Kiva. She aspires to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Nyevu

texts.en: Nyevu is 36 years old and is married and the mother of five children. For the past two years, she has earned a living by selling water in Malindi. Nyevu earns a monthly profit of KES 5,000. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is also a registered client. Nyevu will use the entire loan amount to buy a water tank. In the future, she seeks to continue growing her business so she can help to give her family a good and stable life.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Munuve

texts.en:
Munuve is a resident of the Malindi area of Coast province, Kenya. She is married and has two adult children. Munuve owns a retail shop, a business that she has been running for two years. Besides this, Munuve also owns and runs a curio shop.

She learnt about Milango from other clients and joined the institution with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenge is the effect of poor seasons and fluctuating prices.
 
Munuve is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenyan shillings to purchase foodstuffs like cereals, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve her family's living standard. Munuve aspires to own other shops and to feel secure about paying for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs like cereals, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment for her fishing business. NWTF is relisting Leonida's business profile in support of her efforts to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es:
Amelia tiene 33 años, convive con Hubert, su pareja, y su madre. Ellos viven en una casa propia ubicada cerca de la carretera central. Amelia es una mujer muy empeñosa en las actividades que realiza. Desde los 20 años empezó a trabajar para mantener a su familia. Una de sus funciones es atender su negocio de venta de combustibles, “la ventaja que tengo es que mi casa está cerca a la carretera, por eso siempre hay clientes que viajan por varias rutas”, menciona. A la vez cuenta con un pequeño kiosco donde ofrece comestibles como frutas, panes, manjar blanco de leche pura, quesos y otros que los viajeros llevan hacia sus ciudades de origen. Los días donde tiene más ingresos son los viernes, sábados y domingos, por la mayor cantidad de autos que recorren la ciudad. Lleva como 5 años en este negocio, y dice que le va muy bien, por eso ahora requiere de su apoyo para adquirir más mercadería (comestibles y combustible), para no descuidar a sus clientes. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Progreso Huayounioc”, y éste es su crédito número 10 con MFP, donde es muy puntual en sus cuotas. Hasta el momento es una de las socias más activas en el grupo.
Amelia, invertirá el dinero en la compra de comestibles (quesos, manjar blando, frutas, refrescos y otros), además de combustibles como gasolina.
texts.en:
Amelia, 33, lives with her common-law husband, Hubert, and her mother.  They live in their own house located on the main road.  Amelia is very dedicated to everything she does and for 20 years has been working to support her family.  One of her jobs is attending to her fuel sales business.  "The advantage I have is that my house is close to the road and there are always customers who travel different routes.", she says.  She also has a small kiosk where she sells food such as fruit, bread, fudge, cheese and other items that the travelers buy to take home with them.  

Her busiest days are Friday, Saturday and Sunday because of all the vehicles driving through the city.  She has been in this business for five year and says it is going well.  Now she is requesting your help to buy more merchandise (groceries and fuel) to meet customer demand.  

She belongs to the communal bank "Progreso Huayounioc" and this is her 10th loan through MFP, where she has always been punctual in her payments.  She is one of the most active members of the group at this time.

Amelia will use the loan to buy groceries (cheese, fudge, fruit, soft-drinks and other items), as well as fuels such as gasoline.

loans.use: To buy cheese, fudge, fruit, soft drinks and other items, as well as fuels.

loans.name: Taj

texts.en:
Taj is an energetic 42-year-old married woman. She has had a business selling corn in her community for many years. Taj started her business when her husband was severely injured in an accident and was not in a good enough physical shape to be employed. This compelled her to support her family members' needs and to smoothly manage household expenditures through her business income. 

Taj is a mother of four and is responsible for providing them with good quality food, clothing and education. She has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. Taj has been associated with Kashf for five years and, due to her trust in this institution, she has again requested a loan of 25,000 PKR to purchase more stock of corn and a small cart so her son can assist her in selling corn door-to-door. She expects a boost in her net income through her increased sales. Taj wishes to spend part of the profits for the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of corn and a small cart so her son can assist her in selling corn door-to-door.

loans.name: Abèle Hounwanou

texts.fr: Agée de 35ans, Abèle est mariée et mère de deux enfants scolarisés. Les deux enfants ont respectivement 15ans et 12ans. Elle a un prêt-à-porter où elle vend des habits de femmes depuis quelques années et s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son fonds de commerce et de satisfaire la demande de ses clients, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un financement auprès de Finadev en vue de maximiser son bénéfice et de participer à la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Abèle is 35 years old, married and the mother of two children who attend school. The two children are 15 and 12 years old, respectively.

Abèle has a ready-to-wear clothing shop where she has been selling women's clothing for several years, and for which she gets her supplies in one of Benin's markets. With the goal of strengthening her business and meeting customer demand, Abèle has sought and obtained a loan from Finadev in order to maximize her profits and to contribute to her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase 35 outfits of women's clothing.

loans.name: Brigitte's Group

texts.fr: Il s'agit d'un groupe composé de deux femmes en caution solidaire. Agée de 43ans, Brigitte la responsable est mariée et mère d'un enfant âgé de 21ans qui est déjà à l'université. Elle vend des sacs de maïs depuis 5ans et s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Dans le souci d'augmenter son capital et de répondre favorablement à la demande de ses clients, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un micro crédit à finadev. Le bénéfice dégagé par ce crédit lui permettra de participer à la formation professionnelle de son enfant et de subvenir à ses besoins. Brigitte se retrouve à gauche dans la photo.
texts.en:
This is a group made up of two women who are mutually guaranteeing their loan. Brigitte, the group's leader, is 34 years old, married and the mother of one child who is 21 years old and already attending college.

Brigitte has been selling sacks of corn for five years and gets her supplies in one of Benin's markets. In the hope of increasing her capital and responding favorably to customer demand, she has sought and obtained a micro-loan from Finadev. The profits made possible by this loan will allow her to contribute to her child's vocational training and to meet her needs. Brigitte appears at left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase four sacks of corn.

loans.name: Stephany Lissette

texts.es:
Stephany, una mujer joven de 20 años ha atravesado varios obstáculos en su vida, uno de ellos la dificultad para no poder continuar sus estudios profesionales, pues a pesar de los esfuerzos realizados, logró terminar solo la secundaria. Ahora sale adelante con su pequeño hijo, con quien recibió el reto de educarlo y sustentarlo sola. Juntos viven en Quinidé un cantón de la Provincia de Esmeraldas que provee a varias ciudades del Ecuador productos como banano, cacao, café, palma africana y productos forestales y además el comercio es el trabajo diario de la mayoría de sus habitantes para poder salir adelante y más aún cuando han incrementado las vías para llegar a este cantón lo que ha permitido un gran movimiento comercial en especial los fines de semana en donde salen comerciantes de todo tipo a ofertar sus productos en la feria a sus potenciales clientes que la mayoría de veces suelen ser campesinos. El turismo también es un aporte muy importante para este cantón pues su ecosistema natural tiene mucha variedad de lugares para ser visitados cascadas, ríos de agua dulce,  bosques, que tienen flores y animales que adornan esta ciudad.
Hace 4 años Stephany aprendió con la ayuda de una amiga la actividad de vender cosméticos por catálogo de forma ambulante. A pesar de la separación con su pareja, ella buscó maneras de no descuidar a su hijo pero a la vez dedicando mucho tiempo a su trabajo para tener el sustento. Con la experiencia ella ha aprendido a administrar de manera correcta sus recursos y ahora que su hijo va creciendo, el salir a ofrecer los productos a sus clientes, se le facilita. Todos los días aprovecha las oportunidades y necesidades de sus clientes que en su mayoría son mujeres. Ella se siente lista para dar el siguiente paso de fijar y establecer su negocio en un solo lugar, por lo cual ha decidido asignar un espacio de su casa para ofertar sus productos con descuentos y ofertas que sirvan como estrategia para atraer a sus clientes y así Stephany pueda ganar más utilidades y además pueda dedicar más  tiempo a su hijo. Por esta razón, Stephany solicitó un crédito para poder realizar las adecuaciones necesarias al lugar que designó para la venta de cosméticos como limpieza, pintura, exhibidores, etc. Fundación Alternativa, gracias al trabajo de Kiva pudo brindarle este préstamo y además capacitarle para un correcto funcionamiento de su negocio.
texts.en:
Stephany is a young, 20-year-old woman, who has run into many challenges in her life.  One of them was that she was unable to continue her professional training, despite her hard work, and only finished high school.  Now she is trying to get ahead with her small son, and has the challenge of educating and supporting him.  They live in Quinidé Canton in the province of Esmeraldas which supplies many cities of Ecuador with products such as bananas, cocoa, coffee, African palm and forest products.  Commerce is the main work of the population in this area, especially now that there are more roads leading into this canton, allowing for a good amount of trade, especially on weekends.  That is when all types of merchants go to the markets in search of potential customers, most of whom are farmers.  Tourism is also an important activity for this canton because of its natural ecosystem, with a variety of attractions, such as water falls, sweet water rivers, forests, and the flora and fauna that adorn the city.

Four years ago, Stephany learned from a friend how to sell cosmetics by catalogue, working as a street vendor.  Despite having divorced her husband, she has sought out ways to care for her son, while also working hard to support him.  With experience, she has learned how to manage her income correctly; and now that her son is growing, it is easier for her to go out to offer her products to customers.  Every day she takes advantage of the opportunities and needs of her customers, most of whom are women.  She feels ready to take the next step which is to set up business in one location.  Therefore, she has decided to establish a space in her house where she can offer discounts and sale items as a strategy to attract customers.  Stephany wants to earn more profit and spend more time with her son.  That is why she has requested a loan to fix up a space in her house (by cleaning, painting, installing display cases, etc.) to sell cosmetics.  Fundación Alternativa, thanks to work done by Kiva, was able to give her the loan and train her to run her business correctly.

loans.use: To fix up a space in her house to sell cosmetics.

loans.name: Waliou Olakorédé

texts.fr: Waliou Olakorédé est âgé de 57 ans et vit au Bénin. Waliou Olakorédé est marié à un certain Moudjibath. Le couple a cinq enfants dont certains scolarisés et tous scolarisés à leur charge. En plus de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à charge. Waliou Olakorédé vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants et assure ensemble avec sa femme, les charges de la maison. Afin d’assurer les diverses charges de la famille, Waliou Olakorédé mène comme activité depuis une vingtaine d’année, la profession de meunier. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Waliou Olakorédé sollicite pour la cinquième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt lui permettra de prendre un moulin à maïs pour renforcer ses équipements en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de se faire plus de profits. Les premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Waliou Olakorédé is 57 years old and lives in Benin. Waliou Olakorédé  is married to Moudjibath. The couple has five children, some of whom attend school; all of those attending school are in the couple's care. In addition to their own children, the couple cares for another child. Waliou Olakorédé  lives together with his wife and children, and together he and his wife see to the household expenses.

In order to see to the family's various expenses, Waliou Olakorédé has been working as a miller for some 20 years. With the goal of customer satisfaction and an increase in his revenue, Waliou Olakorédé is seeking his fifth loan from Alidé. This loan will allow him to purchase a corn mill to improve his equipment in order to expand his business and to turn a greater profit. The preceding loans have been properly repaid.

loans.use: To purchase a corn mill.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia tiene 42 años, vive con su esposo Abel y sus 2 hijos. Ellos habitan una casa propia ubicada en un distrito agrícola. Sonia es una mujer activa y responsable. En todos sus años de casada ha realizado varias actividades (agricultura y comercio), pero las labores que no cesan son los negocios. Ella cuenta con kiosco al lado de la carretera donde ofrece combustibles para los autos, buses y camiones que transitan por su zona. “Llevo como 10 años vendiendo combustible y el negocio es rentable”, comenta. Además dice que, cuando los conductores detienen sus movilidades, también consumen alimentos de los kioscos del lugar. 
A la vez se dedica a la agricultura, pero su esposo es quién dispone de la mayor parte de su tiempo en esas actividades. Ella se encarga de preparar los alimentos para los jornaleros y luego vuelve a su negocio. Ésta vez ella necesita de apoyo para adquirir más combustibles y así atender a sus clientes, y así continuar con sus metas hacia el crecimiento. Éste es el crédito número 11 con MFP, y es puntual en el pago de las cuotas. Pertenece al banco comunal “Progreso Huayounioc”, donde participa activamente.
Con el dinero podrá adquirir los combustibles (gasolina y petróleo) que requiere para atender a los viajeros que transitan por su zona.
texts.en:
Sonia, 42, lives with her husband, Abel, and two children in their own house in the farm district.  Sonia is an active, responsible woman who has always worked in several areas (agriculture and commerce) during her married life, but the activity that never ceases is her business.  She has a roadside kiosk where she sells fuel to the automobiles, buses and trucks that travel in her area.  "I have been selling fuel for ten years and business is profitable.", she says.  She claims that when the drivers stop they also buy food from different kiosks in the area.

Sonia is also a farmer, but her husband is the one who spends most of his time in agriculture.  She prepares food for the farm workers and then goes back to her business.  She is need of a loan to buy fuels for her customers, so she can continue with her business expansion goal.  This is her 11th loan through MFP and she has been punctual in her loan payments.  She belongs to the communal bank "Progreso Huayounioc", where she is an active member.

She plans to use the loan to buy fuels (gasoline and oil) to fill the demand of travelers in the area.

loans.use: To buy fuel (gasoline and oil).

loans.name: Alexandre Vihanou

texts.fr: Marié à une coiffeuse du nom de Rosaline, Alexandre Vihanou est âgé de 36 ans. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Alexandre Vihanou et sa femme vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Alexandre Vihanou a peu fréquenté l’école. Il y a près d'une dizaine d'années que Alexandre Vihanou exerce la profession de meunier dans une ville du Bénin. Alexandre Vihanou exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Alexandre Vihanou s’approvisionne dans sa région. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Alexandre Vihanou sollicite un cinquième crédit. Ce crédit lui servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits. Les prêts antérieurs reçus ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Married to a hairdresser by the name of Rosaline, Alexandre Vihanou is 36 years old. The couple has four children, all of them in school. Alexandre Vihanou and his wife live together with their children and, together, see to the various household expenses.

Alexandre Vihanou did not receive much education. He has been working as a miller in a town in Benin for nearly a decade. He undertakes his business with passion, which allows him to meet his needs and those of his children. He gets his supplies from within the region.

With the goal of meeting customer demand, Alexandre Vihanou is seeking a fifth loan. This loan will allow him to better respond to his customers' needs and to make more of a profit. The preceding loans received have been properly repaid.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts.

loans.name: Wangninnou Ives

texts.fr: Wangninnou Ives, est âgée de 32 ans et est marié à Dénise, une marchande. Le couple a six enfants, dont certains scolarisés et tous à leur charge. Parmi les enfants, cinq constituent leurs propres enfants. Wangninnou Ives a arrêté l’école au niveau primaire. Wangninnou Ives vit ensemble avec ses enfants et sa femme. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a de cela dix ans que Wangninnou Ives exerce comme activité, la profession de meunier à son domicile. Wangninnou Ives exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Wangninnou Ives s’approvisionne dans une ville du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et en vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement, Wangninnou Ives sollicite un cinquième crédit. Ce crédit lui servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits. Les crédits précédents ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Wangninnou Ives is 32 years old and is married to Denise, a shopkeeper. The couple has six children, some of whom attend school and all of whom are in their care. Of the children, five are their own.
